G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: The amount in controversy exceeds $50,000, exclusive of interest and costs, thereby placing this matter within the jurisdiction of the Superior Court pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 3.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7\u00a7 1, 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Suffolk County under G.L. c. 223, §§ 1, 2, in that the cause of action arose in Suffolk County, at or near 500 Commonwealth Avenue, Boston, Massachusetts 02215.

G.L. c. 89.proposition: Commonwealth Avenue in that area is a busy public way within the meaning of G.L. c. 89 and G.L. c. 90, regularly used by motor vehicles, bicycles, and pedestrians.

G.L. c. 90.proposition: Commonwealth Avenue in that area is a busy public way within the meaning of G.L. c. 89 and G.L. c. 90, regularly used by motor vehicles, bicycles, and pedestrians.

*See, e.g.,* **Coombes v. Florio**, 450.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every driver of a motor vehicle owes a duty to exercise reasonable care under the circumstances toward all foreseeable users of the road, including bicyclists.
*See, e.g.,* **Coombes v. Florio**, 450.support_reasoning: The provided text is only the brief per curiam disposition reversing summary judgment and remanding, without any of the substantive opinions or reasoning. It contains no discussion of the duty of drivers toward foreseeable users of the road or bicyclists, so based on this excerpt alone, the case cannot be said to support the stated proposition. While the full Coombes v. Florio opinion may address duty issues, that is not discernible from the text supplied.
*See, e.g.,* **Coombes v. Florio**, 450.relevant_excerpt:
The judgment of the Superior Court granting the defendantâs motion for summary judgment is reversed. The case is remanded to the Superior Court for further proceedings.

So ordered.

**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every driver of a motor vehicle owes a duty to exercise reasonable care under the circumstances toward all foreseeable users of the road, including bicyclists.
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u2.support_reasoning: The case does articulate a general tort principle that "every actor" has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, conditioned on foreseeability. However, it does not involve motor vehicles, drivers, roads, or bicyclists, nor does it discuss duties specific to road users. Using Jupin v. Kask as authority for a driver’s duty to foreseeable users of the road, including bicyclists, would therefore be an extension rather than an accurate statement of what the case decides.
**Jupin v. Kask**, 447 Mass. 141, 146\u2.relevant_excerpt: “We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor.”

*See, e.g.,* **Glick v. Prince Italian F.raw_text: *See, e.g.,* **Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.**, 25 Mass. App. Ct. 901, 902–03 (1987)
*See, e.g.,* **Glick v. Prince Italian F.proposition: A motorist owes a duty to maintain a proper lookout for bicyclists and other traffic, to use reasonable care when stopping or parking near lanes of travel, and to avoid creating sudden hazards in areas where bicyclists are known or likely to be.
*See, e.g.,* **Glick v. Prince Italian F.case_name: Glick v. Prince Italian Foods of Saugus, Inc.
*See, e.g.,* **Glick v. Prince Italian F.support_reasoning: The quoted portion of Glick v. Prince Italian Foods deals with premises liability and the foreseeability of injuries from out‑of‑control motor vehicles crashing into a restaurant. It articulates a landowner’s duty based on foreseeable harm and rejects liability where the incident was not reasonably foreseeable. It does not address a motorist’s duty to keep a lookout for bicyclists, to use care when stopping or parking, or to avoid creating sudden hazards to bicyclists, so it does not support the claimed proposition.
*See, e.g.,* **Glick v. Prince Italian F.relevant_excerpt: “A landowner or proprietor is not an insurer of the safety of his patrons. ‘The test is “foreseeable harm.” … The underlying duty in every case, however, is to exercise the care which the circumstances reasonably require.’ Kane v. Fields Corner Grille, Inc., 341 Mass. 640, 642 (1961). Based on the evidence presented, there could be no reasonable difference of opinion as to the improbability of the incident which occurred. … The undisputed facts of this case make the injuries suffered by the plaintiffs the result of an incident which was not reasonably foreseeable by the defendant and thus not an occurrence from which it had a duty to protect its patrons.”

G.L. c. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant also had a specific statutory duty under G.L. c. 90, § 14, which provides in relevant part that “ [n]o person shall open a door on a motor vehicle unless it is reasonably safe to do so without interfering with the movement of other traffic, including bicyclists.”

**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.raw_text: **Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.**, 408 Mass. 355, 359–60 (1990)
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.proposition: Violation of a safety statute is evidence of negligence.
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.case_name: Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store, Inc.
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.support_reasoning: The court squarely addresses the effect of violating a safety statute (G.L. c. 138, § 69) on civil negligence liability. It reiterates Massachusetts law that violation of such a statute is not negligence per se but is "some evidence" of negligence as to the harms the statute was meant to prevent. That directly supports the proposition that violating a safety statute is evidence of negligence (though not conclusive proof).
**Bennett v. Eagle Brook Country Store,.relevant_excerpt: It has long been the rule in this Commonwealth that violation of a statute does not by itself establish a breach of duty, for it does not constitute negligence per se. LaClair v. Silberline Mfg. Co., 379 Mass. 21, 28 (1979), and cases cited. Rather, violation of a statute such as § 69 is only "some evidence" of the defendant's negligence as to all consequences the statute was intended to prevent. Cimino v. Milford Keg, Inc., supra. Adamian v. Three Sons, Inc., 353 Mass. 498, 499 (1968).

**St. Germaine v. Pendergast**, 411 Mass.proposition: Violation of a safety statute is evidence of negligence.
**St. Germaine v. Pendergast**, 411 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the effect of statutory and regulatory violations in negligence actions. The court explicitly states that violations of a statute or regulations do not constitute negligence per se but are only some evidence of negligence, and then reiterates that the safety provisions and regulations in question could be considered by the jury as evidence of negligence. This directly supports the proposition that violation of a safety statute is evidence of negligence.
**St. Germaine v. Pendergast**, 411 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “We do not construe a safety statute to establish a new civil cause of action without express terms or clear legislative intent to that effect. … Nor do violations of a statute or regulations constitute negligence per se; they are only some evidence of negligence. … The various provisions of the State Building Code and other rules and regulations relied upon by the plaintiffs could be considered as evidence of negligence with regard to duties imposed by common law on Pendergast…”

G.L. c. 85, \u00a7 11B.proposition: G.L. c. 85, § 11B recognizes bicycles as vehicles and grants bicyclists the right to use public ways and to ride in bicycle lanes, subject to the same basic rules of the road as drivers of motor vehicles.

**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694, 69.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, negligence consists of a duty of reasonable care, a breach of that duty, causation, and damages.
**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694, 69.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly sets out the elements the plaintiffs must prove in negligence: breach of the duty to use reasonable care, actual loss (damages), and causation, with duty itself assumed as a prerequisite. This matches the standard Massachusetts common-law formulation that negligence consists of duty, breach, causation, and damages, and the court treats causation as an "essential element" of negligence.
**Glidden v. Maglio**, 430 Mass. 694, 69.relevant_excerpt: With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.

**Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.**.proposition: Foreseeability of harm is an essential component of duty and proximate cause; one who creates a foreseeable risk of injury to another through careless conduct may be held liable for the resulting harm.
**Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.**.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly frames the liability question in terms of foreseeability and adopts the general rule that an intervening third party’s act does not break causation if it ought to have been foreseen. The court then holds that it was reasonably foreseeable that leaving the forklift unsecured would result in its misuse and injury to persons like the plaintiff, thus tying foreseeability both to the defendant’s duty to secure the forklift and to proximate cause of the resulting harm.
**Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth.**.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen.… The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated….’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable.… Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

**Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.**, 454.proposition: Foreseeability of harm is an essential component of duty and proximate cause; one who creates a foreseeable risk of injury to another through careless conduct may be held liable for the resulting harm.
**Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.**, 454.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly discusses that liability in negligence requires both cause in fact and that the injury fall within the scope of foreseeable risk, linking foreseeability to proximate cause. It further states that negligence liability is limited to foreseeable risks and that many jurisdictions use a foreseeability test for proximate cause, aligning with the proposition that creating a foreseeable risk of injury through careless conduct can result in liability for resulting harm. Although the hospital ultimately prevailed on lack of foreseeability here, the case affirms the general principle.
**Leavitt v. Brockton Hosp., Inc.**, 454.relevant_excerpt: "The law does not impose liability for all harm factually caused by tortious conduct. Liability for conduct obtains only where the conduct is both a cause in fact of the injury and where the resulting injury is within the scope of the foreseeable risk arising from the negligent conduct. See id. at § 29, at 575; Kent v. Commonwealth, supra at 320 (plaintiff must show cause in fact and that injury was ‘foreseeable result’ of conduct)... ‘Negligence limits the requirement of reasonable care to those risks that are foreseeable.’"

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 85.proposition: Under Massachusetts’ comparative negligence statute, G.L. c. 231, § 85, Plaintiff’s contributory negligence, if any, does not bar recovery so long as it is not greater than the negligence of Defendant, and any damages are diminished in proportion to any causal negligence attributable to Plaintiff.

**Uloth v. City Tank Corp.**, 376 Mass..proposition: The question of negligence, breach of duty, and comparative fault, if any, is for the trier of fact.
**Uloth v. City Tank Corp.**, 376 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns whether directed verdicts and JNOV were properly denied in a product design negligence case, but it does not articulate any general rule that questions of negligence, breach of duty, or comparative fault are for the trier of fact. While the court applies the standard of viewing evidence in the light most favorable to the plaintiff and notes that conflicting testimony and assumption of risk are for the jury, it never states the broad proposition claimed. Comparative fault is not discussed at all.
**Uloth v. City Tank Corp.**, 376 Mass..relevant_excerpt:
Although his testimony concerning his awareness of the danger of the packer panel was contradictory, resolution of conflicting testimony is the jury’s function.

... We cannot conclude as matter of law that Uloth assumed the risk of injury.

**Thompson v. County of Franklin**, 15 M.raw_text: **Thompson v. County of Franklin**, 15 Mass. App. Ct. 974, 975 (1983)
**Thompson v. County of Franklin**, 15 M.proposition: The question of negligence, breach of duty, and comparative fault, if any, is for the trier of fact.
**Thompson v. County of Franklin**, 15 M.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns sufficiency of evidence for a weapons charge, statutory interpretation of a weapons statute, and the consequences of noncompliance with jury waiver requirements. It does not discuss negligence, breach of duty, comparative fault, or allocation of such questions to the trier of fact. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about negligence and comparative fault being for the factfinder.
**Thompson v. County of Franklin**, 15 M.relevant_excerpt: The provided text contains no discussion of negligence, breach of duty, comparative fault, or the role of the trier of fact in resolving such issues; it focuses on weapons possession under G. L. c. 269, § 10 and procedural issues related to a new trial.

**McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. C.raw_text: **McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. Co.**, 398 Mass. 152, 156–57 (1986)
**McGuiggan v. New England Tel. & Tel. C.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for his bodily injury, pain and suffering, lost wages, medical expenses, and property damage proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence.

**Payton v. Abbott Labs**, 386 Mass. 540.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, Plaintiff is entitled to recover damages for his bodily injury, pain and suffering, lost wages, medical expenses, and property damage proximately caused by Defendant’s negligence.
**Payton v. Abbott Labs**, 386 Mass. 540.support_reasoning: The opinion in Payton v. Abbott Labs is focused on emotional distress, prenatal injuries, wrongful life, and market‑share liability. It does not discuss or set out the general measure of damages for a standard negligence action (bodily injury, pain and suffering, lost wages, medical expenses, property damage). The case therefore does not provide authority for the broad proposition about recoverable negligence damages under Massachusetts law and is not an appropriate citation for that point.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Plaintiff is entitled to recover prejudgment interest on his damages as provided by G.L. c. 231, § 6B.
